Hi C=E9dric,

> FYI, a few more reactions and articles on the same topic.  =
It looks like
>  most of the Java and Ruby communities (last link) are typi=
cally using a
>  small portion of TDD and a majority of regular testing, wh=
ich matches my
>  experience.

I don't think anyone ever disagreed that "re=
gular testing" interpreted
to mean automated acceptance testing and unit te=
sting is not done to
the extent we would like to see on this list. I don't =
think anyone
needs to be convinced about this, this is a known fact, one th=
at a lot
of us believe should change. It is in the conclusions that can be
=
derived from that where opinions differ. You seem to say that since
most so=
ftware is not "regularly tested" and most software works great
you can abvi=
ously do perfectly well without "regular testing".

Myself and others have =
argued that most software can work better and
that our acceptance for error=
s is too high. David Saff also made an
interesting comment about all the so=
ftware we don't see, the software
we don't use and the software that is nev=
er released. I think it is
natural that popular software used by many works=
 great, or it
wouldn''t be popular. Popular software can also deferr some t=
esting to
their "beta"-testers and "get away with it". But that is just a s=
mall
fraction of all the software written.

I personally think that you are=
 way wrong that there is code that is
ot tested and works. I think that all=
 software out there is tested,
meaning some effort has been made to ensure =
that it works. There are
hard ways and easy ways to test software. The easy=
 way (I think it is
automated testing) is the most reliable while the hard =
way requires
some guesswork and predictions coupled with manual effort.

I =
followed the first link and got a little bit upset by one of your
transcrip=
tions of a supposedly rethorical answer:

"One response to the question sug=
gests that there are only two types
of code: Code that is tested and works =
and code that is not tested and
doesn't work. Cedric's take on the subject =
is that there are ways of
knowing that your code is working without actuall=
y testing it. So we
should also include a third category: Code that is not =
tested and
works."

That was your subjective interpretation of what Robert =
C Martin wrote.
When you asked for clarification you asked:

"You seem to i=
mply that there are only two kinds of code:

 - Code that is tested and wor=
ks
 - Code that is not tested and doesn't work

There is actually something=
 in the middle: it's called "Code that
is not
tested but that works"."

Tha=
t was the interpretation you used in the blog-entry.
The reply came:

"The =
two kinds of code are:

- Code you have tested, and you know works to the b=
est of your
ability to determine.
- Code you have not tested and don't know=
 if it works.

If you haven't tested the code, you don't know that it works=
. If you
HAVE tested the code then you know that it passes your tests."


W=
hy didn't you just post the statement as it was written instead of
your sub=
jective interpretation? Your interpretation sure has more
punch that the re=
al thing but it is obviously  not what the author
meant.

I really admire y=
ou taking a stand in this discussion and in this
forum. A lot of really goo=
d discussion has come out of it and not many
are so brave as you are to go =
against the flow on a board like this.
But when you post subjective interpr=
etaions like the one above you
loose credibility, atleast with me. And I th=
ink that is a shame
because you obviously have a message that you want to g=
et through
with. I think your opinions deserves to be listened to and evalu=
ated.

I didn't read the rest of the links or the comments, perhaps somethi=
ng
more interesting or would have com up there.

Just one mans opinion
/J
